Bootstrapping is a way of assigning confidence to a tree. Pseudoreplicates are created through an iterative resampling process. If you have a dataset (set of sequences in this case) of n sequences with m sites (bases or nucleotides), a number of resampled datasets are produced, and each site is sampled at random a number of times. These resampled datasets are used to produce a number of trees which are then all reconciled in order to produce one tree with confidence/bootstrap scores included. Generally, a good number of bootstraps is 500 - 1000 (depending on the time and computing power and size of dataset). Generally, a good number of bootstraps is 500 - 1000 (depending on the time and computing power and size of dataset). Instructor's Post
The work you do on any object is the force you exert on that object times the distance that object moves in the direction of your force on it. Nothing else matters -- not friction, air resistance, or anything else. If you do work on the object according to that rule, then you are definitely transferring energy to the object. If there are other forces acting on the object, then they may also be doing work (or negative work) on the object. For example, if you are pushing a desk across the floor, you are doing work on it according to the rule: your work is equal to the force you exert on the desk times the distance the desk moves in the direction of your force on the desk. But the floor is exerting a frictional force on the desk's legs and the desk is moving a distance in the direction opposite to the floor's force on the desk. As a result, the floor is doing negative work on the desk! So you are transferring energy to the desk and the floor is removing that energy from the desk (by way of friction). The missing energy -- the energy removed from the desk by friction -- ends up as thermal energy in the floor surface and bottom of the legs. Lou

To answer this question, let's take a detailed look at what is exerting a torque on what. Suppose we have a boy and a girl riding on a seesaw. We will assume that the center of rotation is the seesaw's pivot, so all the torques will be defined as around that point. I'll list all the torques that the four objects in the story exert directly on one another (or 'produce' by way of a force). It's actually a long list: [Note: The four objects are the boy, the girl, the seesaw, and the Earth (which includes the ground on which the seesaw is mounted).] 1. gravity exerts a torque on the boy (around the seesaw's pivot) 2. gravity exerts a torque on the girl 3. gravity exerts a torque on the seesaw itself, but only if that seesaw is not balance properly 4-6. gravity exerts a torque on the Earth due to the boy, girl, and seesaw respectively (the Newton's third law pairs of 1, 2, and 3) 7. the boy exerts a torque on the seesaw 8. the seesaw exerts a torque on the boy 9. the girl exerts a torque on the seesaw 10. the seesaw exerts a torque on the girl 11. The ground's torque on the boy if he touches it 12. The boy's torque on the ground if he touches it. 13. The ground's torque on the girl if she touches it. 14. The girl's torque on the ground if she touches it. 15. The ground's torque on the seesaw if the seesaw touches the ground 16. The seesaw's torque on the ground if the seesaw touches the ground The net torque on the boy is the sum of 1, 8, and 11. The net torque on the girl is the sum of 2, 10, and 13. The net torque on the seesaw is the sum of 3, 7, 9, and 15. The net torque on the earth & ground is the sum of 4, 5, 6, 12, 14, 16 Each object undergoes angular acceleration in response to the net force acting on it. Because of their contact to one another, the various objects tend to move together -- which means that the torques they exert on one another are strongly influenced by their contact with one another. In other words, the boy undergoes angular accelerate on his own, but the seesaw beneath him is likely to undergo the same angular acceleration because of the torques those two objects exert on one another. My in-video statement 'the boy exerts a torque on the girl' is somewhat misleading. That torque of boy on girl is indirect -- they don't touch and thus can't directly exert torques on one another [neglecting gravity between the boy and girl, which is too weak to notice]. Instead, the boy exerts a torque on the seesaw and the seesaw exerts a torque on the girl. The same with transferring energy -- if the boy is descending and the girl is ascending, then the boy is doing work on the seesaw and the seesaw is doing work on the girl, so energy flows from the boy to the seesaw to the girl. The way I want you to think about the seesaw in that video is as a transfer device -- it is allowing the boy to exert a torque on the girl (albeit indirectly) and it is conveying energy from the boy to the girl (again, indirectly). If the seesaw is motionless, then there is no work being done by anything on anything else -- work requires motion. Lou

A skydiver descending through calm air experiences an upward force from the air -- air resistance, or technically pressure drag. That upward drag force increases approximately in proportion to the square of the skydiver's speed through the air. So the faster the skydiver moves downward, the bigger that upward aerodynamic force becomes. When a wagon is on a ramp, they exert support forces on one another. The wagon exerts a support force on the ramp and the ramp exerts a support force on the wagon. Like all support forces, they act perpendicular (at right angles) to the touching surfaces and are therefore not vertical. The ramp pushes the wagon up at angle and the wagon pushes in the opposite direction. Because those two forces are a Newton's third law pair, they are equal in amount but opposite in direction. Those two forces are indeed on different objects, so they can't possibly cancel on another. The wagon's weight, however, has no direct relationship with the support forces. That weight points directly downward. There are thus two forces acting on the wagon: (1) the ramp's for on the wagon, which points up at angle, and (2) the wagon's weight, which points downward. Those two forces on the wagon cannot cancel because they don't point in opposite directions. When you add two vector quantities that aren't pointing along the same axis, they can't sum to zero. In this case, the sum yields a residue downhill net force. The wagon accelerates downhill in response to that net force. As for holding a heavy rock motionless, you do no work on the rock. You are pushing up on the rock to support so that it doesn't fall, but it moves no distance in the direction of your force. The rock receives no energy from you and it's total energy doesn't change. It still has the same gravitational potential energy (its altitude is constant, after all) and it still has the same kinetic energy (its velocity is zero and staying zero). But while you aren't transferring energy to the rock, you are transforming energy within your body from one form (chemical potential energy) to another form (thermal energy). You are essentially burning your food calories in your muscles and turning that energy into thermal energy -- the energy associated with temperature. You get tired and hot as a result, even though no energy leaves your body (I'm neglecting thermal energy that flows as heat to your colder surroundings). Bottom line: people don't make good statues. A statue could hold the rock up forever without any energy issues at all. There would be no transfers between statue and the rock, and the statue and rock would each have a constant energy. Lou

Instructor's Post
In general, thermal energy is not nearly as useful as ordered forms of energy. For statistical reasons, ordered energy that has been ground into thermal (disordered) energy won't spontaneously turn back into ordered energy. Reordering that thermal energy will require consuming some other form of order. In an isolated system that is all at the same temperature, the thermal energy itself has no order available and none of it can become ordered energy without some external intervention [although there may be some other forms of order around that complicate the story]. However, if parts of that isolated system have different temperatures, there is order associated with those different temperatures and that order can be used to turn some of the thermal energy into ordered energy. That concept, in which a fraction of the heat flowing from a hotter thermal reservoir to a colder thermal reservoir is diverted and becomes useful work, is known as a heat engine. Basically, a heat engine uses the order in a two-temperature system to convert a portion of thermal energy into work while obeying Thermodynamics (mostly the 2nd law, or 'law of entropy'). In your cooking discussions, there are two temperatures: the hot oven and the cold food. There is order in that temperature difference and it is this order that allows all sorts of interesting things to happen as you cook. The food can change shape, make noise, undergo chemical changes, and so on, many of which involve ordered activities. The two-temperature situation provides the necessary order. Once everything is at the same temperature, the order is gone (at least the thermal energy portion of it) and not much new will happen. Lou

Interesting question! Suppose you are talking on the telephone with a person (Bob) in another galaxy. You and Bob have never met and Bob has never seen anything from our world. Now imagine trying to explain to Bob how to draw our standard 3-axis coordinate system (xyz). You first ask Bob to draw the x-axis and y at right angles to one another. Now you ask Bob to add a z-axis at right angles to both of the x-axis and the y-axis. Bob immediately discovers that there is an ambiguity: in which of two possible directions should the z-axis point? You are looking at your mathematics book, which has a properly drawn xyz coordinate system and try to explain to Bob the direction of the z-axis. But you fail. There is absolutely no way for you to identify it over the telephone. You are truly stuck. The two possible xyz coordinate systems that Bob is trying to decide between are mirror images of one another. That mirror symmetry can't be broken over the phone; it can only be broken by making an arbitrary choice and then showing Bob your choice. You must show Bob an artefact that has a unique 'handedness'. Once you do that, you and Bob have a starting point on which to break the mirror symmetry of any other object, including the xyz coordinate system. For example, if you give the person a right shoe (as opposed to a left shoe), now you can use that artefact to specify what you consider to be the correct xyz arrangement. It turns out that particle physics breaks mirror symmetry in rare cases. It is therefore possible to tell Bob to do some elaborate physics measurements and thereby obtain a local reference with which to determine which xyz coordinate system is our standard. During its first second of falling, the bowling ball goes from moving at velocity = 0 to velocity = 10 m/s downward. Title: Warhol's Homosexuality and Art - Culture
inst_post:
Instructor's Post
There's a really interesting point here to raise about language and labelling, I think. Warhol produced some of his most famous work before the gay rights movement kicked off in the late 1960s. (The Stonewall riots occurred in 1969.) During the 50s and 60s, when he was working in New York, the word 'queer' (used, for the most part, pejoratively) would have been in wide circulation. One of the many things that can be taken from Warhol's POPism is the different terms that are used by Warhol to refer to his own sexuality, and that of some of the others at the Factory: swish, homosexual, fag. There are certainly accounts of Warhol's private life in which we can clearly identify him as gay - that is, having emotional and sexual relationships with other men. (The most explicit of these, if probably the most factually unreliable, if John Giorno's extraordinary You've Got To Burn To Shine .) In recent years, Warhol has been 'claimed' by queer theory, which retrospectively reads him and his work as challenging concrete definitions of gender and sexuality. Jennifer, the term 'queer' is problematic for a lot of people - gay and straight. But what is useful to think through is the different ways in which the word has been mobilised in different historical periods, and how it can be politically useful.

Walter Benjamin's seminal 'The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction' (1936) discusses the change in the way people see works of art once they are surrounded by copies. I have always thought it telling that he speaks in terms of power--the authority of the original ( its aura) is dependent on our perception of it as singular but also on some ineffable unreproducible uniqueness. This may work for painting and sculpture but clearly does not for AW's chosen media: film, photography and silk screen, all of which can be said to have no singular original. This is even more the case with digital images that are infinitely repeatable AND lacking in materiality. Thank you Alison for bringing this up. You are right in thinking that this essay might be useful in order to understand Warhol's use of reproductive techniques and processes. There are two sides of Benjamin's essay however. The first, which you mention, is the negative reading of mechanical reproduction, as something which de-auratizes the work, leaving it detached from tradition and historical meaning. Here is a quote from the essay in support of this: 'The authenticity of a thing is the essence of all that is transmissible from its beginning, ranging from its substantive duration to its testimony to the history which it has experienced. Since the historical testimony rests on the authenticity, the former, too, is jeopardized by reproduction when substantive duration ceases to matter. And what is really jeopardized when the historical testimony is affected is the authority of the object. One might subsume the eliminated element in the term 'aura' and go on to say: that which withers in the age of mechanical reproduction is the aura of the work of art. This is a symptomatic process whose significance points beyond the realm of art. One might generalize by saying: the technique of reproduction detaches the reproduced object from the domain of tradition.' However Benjamin suggests that we can also see the de-auratized work as positive: something more democratic and political.He writes: 'An analysis of art in the age of mechanical reproduction must do justice to these relationships, for they lead us to an all-important insight: for the first time in world history, mechanical reproduction emancipates the work of art from its parasitical dependence on ritual. To an ever greater degree the work of art reproduced becomes the work of art designed for reproducibility. From a photographic negative, for example, one can make any number of prints; to ask for the 'authentic' print makes no sense. But the instant the criterion of authenticity ceases to be applicable to artistic production, the total function of art is reversed. Instead of being based on ritual, it begins to be based on another practice â€“ politics.' Can Warhol's work be read in this way? Or would you see his use of reproductive processes as something which empties the work of everything: both 'ritual' and 'politics'?
